message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pulmonary embolism (PE), which can be confirmed by a chest CT scan showing a wedge-shaped filling defect. Thrombus in the left atrium on TEE is usually seen in patients with atrial fibrillation. Tracheal deviation is not a common finding in PE. Elevated serum CK-MB is seen in patients with myocardial infarction, which is not suggested by the patient’s symptoms and physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and risk factors suggest pulmonary embolism. A chest CT scan is the imaging test of choice and will most likely show a wedge-shaped filling defect. Thrombus in the left atrium is more likely to cause systemic embolization and is not related to the patient’s symptoms. Tracheal deviation occurs in tension pneumothorax, which is not likely given the patient’s symptoms. Elevated serum CK-MB suggests myocardial infarction, which is not likely given the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough with bloody sputum, which suggests pulmonary embolism. The decreased breath sounds over the left lung base and calf pain on dorsal flexion of the right foot suggests a deep vein thrombosis. Chest CT is the best tool to diagnose pulmonary embolism and will show a wedge-shaped filling defect. Thrombus in the left atrium on TEE and tracheal deviation on CXR are not related to this patient's symptoms, and elevated serum CK-MB likely indicates myocardial infarction, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism. The chest CT will most likely show a wedge-shaped filling defect, which is a classic finding for pulmonary embolism. Thrombus in the left atrium on TEE would suggest a different diagnosis such as atrial fibrillation. Tracheal deviation on CXR would suggest a different diagnosis such as tension pneumothorax. Elevated serum CK-MB would suggest a different diagnosis such as myocardial infarction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including chest pain, shortness of breath, cough with bloody sputum, and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base, suggest pulmonary embolism. Smoking, oral contraceptives, and immobility after furniture moving are all risk factors for pulmonary embolism. The calf pain on dorsal flexion of the right foot indicates a positive Homan sign, which is also suggestive of pulmonary embolism. A CT scan is the most commonly used imaging modality to diagnose pulmonary embolism, and a wedge-shaped filling defect is a classic finding on chest CT. Options A, C, and D are not directly related to the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest a pulmonary embolism. Among the options, a wedge-shaped filling defect on chest CT is the most likely finding in this case. Thrombus in the left atrium on TEE is unlikely since there is no indication of atrial fibrillation or valvular disease. Tracheal deviation on CXR is unlikely since the patient’s physical examination does not suggest tension pneumothorax. Elevated serum CK-MB is not specific to pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a pulmonary embolism. The chest CT is the best test to diagnose a pulmonary embolism, which presents as a wedge-shaped filling defect. The other options are less likely and not associated with a pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and risk factors suggest pulmonary embolism (PE). A wedge-shaped filling defect on chest CT is the most likely finding in this case. Thrombus in the left atrium on TEE would suggest atrial fibrillation, which is not mentioned in the case. Tracheal deviation on CXR would suggest tension pneumothorax, which is not consistent with the physical examination findings. Elevated serum CK-MB would suggest myocardial infarction, which is not supported by the symptoms and physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a pulmonary embolism, and the history of smoking and birth control increases the risk. The physical exam findings of decreased breath sounds over the left lung base and calf pain on dorsal flexion of the right foot are also suggestive of pulmonary embolism. The most likely finding on further evaluation would be a wedge-shaped filling defect on chest CT. Option (A) and (C) are not related to the symptoms or physical exam findings. We refer to the patient’s symptoms and medical history to determine the most likely cause. The patient has chest pain, shortness of breath, cough with bloody sputum, and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base, all of which suggest a pulmonary embolism. The risk factors of smoking, oral contraceptive use, and recent immobility (moving furniture) further support this diagnosis. The calf pain on dorsal flexion of the right foot indicates possible deep vein thrombosis. A chest CT is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism and may reveal a wedge-shaped filling defect. The other options are less likely to be found in this patient. A thrombus in the left atrium is a possible finding in patients with atrial fibrillation but was not indicated in this patient’s presentation. Tracheal deviation may occur with tension pneumothorax but was not indicated in this patient’s exam. Elevated serum CK-MB is a marker of cardiac damage, which is not likely the cause of this patient’s symptoms.
